text: eggs are among the simplest and most
versatile ingredients in the kitchen
today I'm going to show you the basics
and that is hard boiling and soft
boiling eggs the real difference is only
a matter of minutes so make sure you set
your timer here otherwise you're going
to end up with this and I know a lot of
us have experienced this an egg yolk
with a gray or greenish exterior to it
and these are overcooked eggs and nobody
wants these so to start off I'm going to
show you hard boiling I have three eggs
here I'm going to go into a small pot
cover the eggs with water you want to
make sure you're about an inch over the
eggs with the water bring this up to a
boil and then you're going to turn off
the heat and cover the pot and let the
eggs sit in the water for anywhere from
6 to 11 minutes depending on how you
like your eggs the eggs have come up to
a boil I'm going to turn the heat off
and I'm going to set my timer for 6
minutes which is the first batch of eggs
that I need to pull out our eggs are out
I have a six-minute egg an 8 minute egg
and an 11 minute egg and to peel the
eggs you can either do the method where
you tap on the board or you can place
your palm on the egg directly and give
it a roll and it kind of cracks up the
egg in a nice even fashion it is said
that older eggs or eggs that aren't as
fresh peel better and that is really
true
but one thing you can do you can add a
good amount of vinegar to the water when
you're boiling your eggs and that will
also help you peel the eggshell away
without nicking up your eggs
here I have my six-minute egg a
six-minute egg has a nice almost creamy
yolk you can see that it's not too dry
the egg whites themselves are not too
tough and rubbery this is really my
preference for a hard-boiled egg so now
for the 8-minute egg give it a tap on
the ends there gently roll it don't
exert too much pressure or you'll
actually bust the egg and
I usually give them a little bit of a
rinse to get any little particles of
eggshell off you can see this
eight-minute egg has a fully cooked yolk
but it's not as dry and crumbly as the
11-minute egg will be nice beautiful
color and the 11 minute egg is just like
this and of course we have that over
cooked egg so now for the soft-boiled
eggs I have a pot of boiling water here
gently place the eggs into the bottom of
the pot do this quickly but gently and
then I'm going to turn the heat off
cover and set the timer for four to six
minutes depending on how you like your
soft-boiled egg but set it for four to
start so there's the timer it's been
four minutes lift the eggs out you want
to make sure that when you place your
eggs in an egg cup just like this that
you serve it immediately the narrow side
of the egg up and then taking a sharp
knife give the egg a good whack careful
they're really really hot here a perfect
soft-boiled egg the yolk is still very
runny the white is nice and custardy be
wonderful if you served it with some of
those little toast soldiers to dunk in
the runny yolk and there you have it
eggs 101 hard-boiled eggs soft-boiled
eggs if you have any kitchen conundrums
write in the comments section below or
reach out to me using the hashtag
kitchen conundrums and I will solve
whatever kitchen problems you may have
enjoy
